results.title: Ballad of a soldier = Ballada o soldate
results.creator_credit: Grigori Chukhrai, M Chernova and Mosfilm
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Films of the great victory 1941-1945”.
Amid the chaos of WW2, a young Russian soldier earns a pass home, for an act of heroism. En route he is detained constantly, as he helps others on their way, managing only the briefest of encounters with his forlorn mother, before returning to active duty. This acclaimed drama speaks of the hardship of war as experienced by the Russian people and of the sadness of separation. It also depicts the sensuality of youth, a theme previously denied Russian filmmakers, but allowed during the “thaw” as it was known, a period in the 1950s of Soviet cinema.

results.title: Torn curtain
results.brief_description: Hitchcock’s 50th film, set during the Cold War, repeats his successful espionage-thriller theme. Paul Newman portrays American nuclear physicist Michael Armstrong who fakes defection to East Germany in order to obtain Communist defence secrets. His fiance and assistant, Sarah Sherman (Julie Andrews) aroused by Armstrong’s suspicious behaviour yet unaware of his intentions, follows him behind the iron curtain. When she realises her fiance’s intentions, she joins him in his effort to obtain secret information and return safely to the United States. Also stars Lila Kedrova, Hansjoerg Felmy, David Opatoshu, and Ludwig Donath. Cinematography by John F. Warren. Written by Brian Moore. Music by John Addison.

results.title: Torment = L' Enfer
results.creator_credit: Claude Chabrol, Marin Karmitz, Cinemanuel, France 3 Cinema, S A CED Productions and MK2 Productions
results.brief_description: This highly successful thriller from one of France’s most renowned and revered directors is set in the countryside of South western France. Hoteliers Nelly (Emmanuel Beart) and Paul (Francois Cluzet) have a marriage made in heaven. Paul is proud of his exceptionally beautiful wife, and Nelly blossoms, radiating a heady mix of innocence and sexuality that is openly admired by their male customers. However, their happiness is threatened when Paul begins to spy on his wife and becomes convinced of her infidelity. His obsessive jealousy turns to anger, which erupts in a cruel and violent climax. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: Tora! tora! tora!
results.creator_credit: Kinji Fukasaku, Toshio Masuda, Richard Fleischer, Elmo Williams and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Tora! Tora! Tora! was an epic and expensive production that attempted to present realistically the battle for Pearl Harbour and the ensuing warring between the American and Japanese armies in World War II. In a unique approach, the battle is presented from both sides, rejecting traditional notions of one-sided jingoistic storytelling, typical of many war films from the 50s and 60s. For the Japanese section directors Toshio Masuda and Kinji Fukasaku pay close attention to the military manoeuvring and blunders of the campaign as well as the infighting and personal clashes within the high command. For the American section, the army is depicted as unsuspecting of an attack of this scale, hampered by limited technology and a lack of foresight. Exciting battle sequences and detailed inner-sanctum decision making within both sides of the battle make “Tora! Tora! Tora!” an interesting war movie that is not simplistic in its politics and is effective in its recreation of a historically significant event. Cast includes Martin Balsam, So Yamamura, Joseph Cotton, Tatsuya Mihashi, E.G. Marshall, James Whitemore, Takahiro Tamura, Eijiro Tono, Jason Robards.

results.title: These three
results.creator_credit: William Wyler, Samuel Goldwyn and Samuel Goldwyn Company
results.brief_description: This cinematic masterpiece, directed with enormous sensitivity by William Wyler, tells the story of two women (Merle Oberon and Miriam Hopkins) who fall in love with the same man (Joel McCrea) and the damage to their lives that can be caused to all three by the malicious lies of a spiteful teenage schoolgirl (Bonita Granville). This powerful story of gossip and suspicion was based on Lillian Hellman’s controversial Broadway success “The Children’s Hour.” The appearance of Walter Brennan as the local taxi driver brings the only light relief to such a dramatic film and the outstanding performance of Bonita Granville was nominated for an Academy Award.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter Weir, Adam Schroeder, Edward S. Feldman, Andrew Niccol, Scott Rudin and Paramount Pictures
results.description: Truman Burbank (Jim Carrey) is the star of a television experiment: he does not know that since birth his life has been the centre of a television show called The Truman Show. The world he lives in is one giant TV set and his family, his marriage and his work are all shams. Gradually, however, Truman comes to suspect that there is something not quite right with his life. As Truman attempts to discover the truth behind the banality of his existence, his attempts are frustrated by the control and power of the man (Ed Harris) who has created “his” life; and by the expectations of a TV audience who have themselves grown up on The Truman Show. From this fantastical premise, Peter Weir has created a moving fable about our obsession with media and the destructive potential of such obsession. Truman exists in a world where reality is meaningless but the film posits that the audiences who watch his life unfold on television are themselves blind to the distinction between media and the real. Weir has crafted a morality tale which utilises the best of contemporary studio craft to present a tale with the simple force and grace of a modern fairy tale.
